name: Virtual Desktop
description: Virtual Desktop is an application developed for the Oculus Rift, HTC Vive and WMR headsets that lets you use your computer in VR. You can browse the web, watch movies, Netflix or even play games on a giant virtual screen.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 SP1, Windows 8.1 or Windows 10 Processor: i5-2500k Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: NVidia GTX 640 or 980M or ATI HD 7000/Rx 200 DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 700 MB available space Additional Notes: Disabling Aero can improve performance on Windows 7. If you are using a Windows 'N' edition, you will need to install the Media Feature Pack.
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 10 Processor: i5-2500k Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: NVidia GTX 760 or 980M or ATI Rx 200 DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 700 MB available space Additional Notes: Windows 10 is highly recommended as it provides better performance. The Anniversary and Creators Update add 8K video and some H.265 support.

Extremely useable - no lag or resolution issues and very customisable. Makes using your desktop in VR a comfortable reality.  There's a few small bugs (milkdrop background clipped off the sides of my taskbar, had a few crashes) but that's to be expected this close to launch.  Looking forward to seeing how this improves over time - it'd be nice to see the video player get increased functionality and for the Millkdrop background to use Milkdrops 3D stereo functionality.

Using this on Oculus CV1.  Looks great, awesome tool. Voice support was unexpected, but very cool. Hopefully it adds more commands in time.  Biggest complaint is that 3D SBS videos need to be pushed in or out and fov experimented with (when played back with VLC). The built in 360/180 video player doesn't work well with a lot of high resolution (4k) content actually. I'm not sure if 4k is the actual cause of the issue (might be codec/fps etc), but it seems to be the issue. This is why I'm using fullscreen in VLC as a workaround. The direct to headset feature of the SBS looks like it could be the best option for this, but never lines up correctly for me. It definitely needs some sort of horizontal eye spacing adjustment or something because its close but not quite there.  My Wishlist: *SBS 3D direct to headset - pupilary distance adjustment options *Built in 360/180 video player - support more content (4k,60fps seems to be the issue mainly) *Game support so any game can be rendered in stereoscopic 3D *Hopefully in the future it can allow virtual monitors so we can have more virtual monitors than real monitors.

Great but could be even better.  My one big gripe is that even though you have an 'infinite' virtual space, you're limited by the amount of desktop space of your physical monitor (even if you're not using it). So, if you (like me) have 1 monitor at 1080p, then you're limited to 1 virtual screen at 1080p. There's no real reason this should be the case (except perhaps technical challenges). I've been searching for ways to trick Windows into thinking I have a second monitor even though I don't, just to get more screen space. That's a little silly.  I also think it would be awesome if you could move windows around independently of the virtual 'screen'. Perhaps move them around in the z-axis or just away from the screen. Again, this is probably not easy, but I would love it if it was possible.  This is a great, solid product. My favorite feature is that you can have the screen 'floating' so that you can center the screen not just horizontally but also vertically. This means I can put the screens on my ceiling and lay flat in bed! Every VR app should have this feature!!!  9/10

VIVE review. I have tried just about every game I play on Virtual Desktop. As of now, I give it a 7/10 completion score. The difference between this and BigScreen Beta is the transparent desktop and customization features. In games, you may run into...  THE problem: black screen flickering during menus but (often) not in gameplay -- so before you start messing with your graphics settings, actually try playing the game to see if the black strobing exists. If it strobes during gameplay, try turning on or off VSync, which almost always fixes it. If that does not fix your problem, ensure you're not using MSAA in the VIRTUAL DESKTOP settings (as it does nto play nice with AA in games), and possibly consider tweaking your AA in game (I keep Virtual Desktop's MSAA turned off by default, I see no difference with it on anyway). Still, some games just will not lose the strobe, and it is quite an unplayable experience. Fix the strobe, and this will the major contender for best premium VR desktop viewer.

I found Virtual Desktop to be really good for what it intends to be. It isn't perfect, but it provides a lot of great functionality.  My setup: Rift running VD from Steam. I borrowed a Rift while I wait for a Vive. So, I did not use VD through Oculus Home.  Purpose: I saw VD on Rift DK1 a while ago and it seemed like a good utility. There are times when I need my desktop in VR. Later I was impressed with the added tools for using your PC in VR. Finally, I was very interested in how well playing regular PC games through VD.  In general, I was very pleased. The general effect was that my monitor was closer to my face. With the curved option (recommended), it worked really well. I found myself making the desktop larger rather than smaller to get me closer. With my screen filling my vision, I could see everything easily. If the screen gets small (so you don't have to move your head as much), the text quality suffers because of the resolution of the headset.  I watched some video, but I was really focused on gaming. I feared that one could only play in Cinema mode, but I found that to NOT be the case. I was pleased to see the full screen display, and I was excited to see what it looked like. I played ESO, Fallout 4, and WoW.  The World of Warcraft I am a long-time WoW player. Entering the world with the VR headset changed the whole world. All I saw was the game world. With the curved view, there was an illusion of being surrounded. The display was 2D, but my vision almost made it 3D. I went to first person and it was the first time I felt like being in that location. Your sense of scale changes.  Elder Scrolls Online ESO was amazing and really looked great. For some reason, and I really don't know why, but the size of everything around me in ESO seemed correct. Once again, I really felt a new level of immersion and almost as if I was there.  Fallout 4 I had some difficulties getting this one to work at first. In general, I found that if you had problems, make sure to start the game from it's original launcher (to fix the load error message), and put the game in Windowed (Fullscreen) mode. Fullscreen didn't always show in the headset. Fallout 4 did not seem quite the right size. Making the screen smaller in the VD settings helped some, but then the top and bottom edges show more and that detracts from the effect. Fallout 4 just seemed too big. This may be subjected, but it seemed somehow my brain started comparing sizes and things just seemed too big (unlike ESO, which just seemed right).  I like having the games list in the VD app, but some games worked from there while others didn't. However, if I launched titles normally, they worked.  I did have some issues. The biggest is that if there was some kind of Windows Security warning (UAC), it didn't show on the headset monitor. There was no dimming either. I had no idea that there was a message until I took the headset off and looked at the real monitor.  Keyboard use was awkward. I am a touch typist, so I could do it, but if someone is not, the keyboard is useless. However, for a desktop replacement, I require a keyboard. The Vive may solve that with its web cam, but with the Rift, I struggled some.  Because the desktop displays a view from a physical monitor, the utility is reduced some. However, for me, having my nose practically to the screen made it worth it. With a physically smaller monitor, a headset user could enlarge the view to see a much better picture. The game screens blow away normal views right out of the water. That reason alone makes this a good purchase for me.  Some folks may be put-off by an apparent roughness to the image; however, that is a quality of the headset and NOT Virtual Desktop.  In the future, I would like to see the following: 1. Show all message on the Virtual Deskop instead of only on the physical screen (probably the primary display). 2. Integrate something to mimic the keyboard, even if it is a gamepad keyboard.  I really like Virtual Desktop. I can't replace every day use yet, but I will play my games with it as much as I can.

I will recap my refund request here to show what the shortcomings of the application are:  No multi-monitor support for virtual monitors. After testing 4-5 different multimonitor emulating programs, I was not able to get it to detect a display, although windows was definitely doing so with several different configurations, and this was my real goal for getting this, to have multiple workspaces.  This one was my bad, as I did not read/trust enough reviews thoroughly to avoid this product. That's on me, for that I wouldn't request a refund.   Key features the store page advertises, though, did cause me to seek one. I would have bit the bullet and only been slightly disappointed if the other features worked fine, since I was the one who screwed up, not the dev. Unfortunately, that was not the case.  After playing around with troubleshooting/reconfiguring/begging google for a forum with some magic voodoo fix for the bugs, I was not able to use the features as follows: Youtube/Saved video support in its video viewer. All would return an error message, despite attempting several workarounds even.   Then, the background inexplicably left the screen and all I had was a desktop floating in void. This seems to be the most basic draw of the program, yet it was unsuccessful  Some of the other features either had limited effect on the experience, if any, and since most of the core components were broken, I decided the product was pointless so I decided to seek a refund at that time.   I still love the idea and may re-purchase in the future if I can get confirmation of the application working as described and with those added benefits, but as of now it is not worth the money it asks, and I tend to be fairly skeptical of negative reviews on VR, considering many of my preferred games on the Vive have mixed or lower end positive ratings.  I will list the positives as well, as I have seen reviews comment on the pixelation. It isn't that distracting, and there are some nice touches. When it worked, the milkdrop settings and the backgrounds were indeed impressive and would have nearly sold me on it if they had worked past the first 10 minutes. Tracked motion controls for me were not a big problem, I'm familiar enough with my keyboard to use it comfortably.  Cons that also wouldn't make me request a refund or even leave negative feedback would include: no 'drag and drop' functionality for the virtual monitor, limited size configuration(it's good, but still left some to be desired)  HMD: HTC vive
